user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_get_free:
```c
size_t
MHD_pool_get_free (struct MemoryPool *pool)
{
  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
#ifdef MHD_ASAN_POISON_ACTIVE
  if ((pool->end - pool->pos) <= _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE)
    return 0;
#endif /* MHD_ASAN_POISON_ACTIVE */
  return (pool->end - pool->pos) - _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if ((pool->end - pool->pos) <= _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE)
    return 0;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the controlling expression ((pool->end - pool->pos) <= _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE) depends on runtime members of the pool object (pool->end and pool->pos) and therefore is not an invariant compile‑time constant. It is not one of the allowed constant-expression exceptions, but that is irrelevant because the expression is not invariant.
